articles.headline: Self-Driving Uber Car Kills Pedestrian in Arizona, Where Robots Roam
articles.snippet: A woman in Tempe, Ariz., died after being hit by a self-driving car operated by Uber, in what is believed to be the first fatality of a pedestrian from an autonomous vehicle on public roads.
articles.abstract: A woman in Tempe, Ariz., died after being hit by a self-driving car operated by Uber, in what is believed to be the first fatality of a pedestrian from an autonomous vehicle on public roads.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Arizona officials saw opportunity when Uber and other companies began testing driverless cars a few years ago. Promising to keep oversight light, they invited the companies to test their robotic vehicles on the state’s roads.

articles.headline: Cambridge Analytica, Trump-Tied Political Firm, Offered to Entrap Politicians
articles.snippet: A British TV station sent a reporter to pose as a prospective client, and secretly filmed Cambridge Analytica’s chief executive offering to engage in dirty tricks.
articles.abstract: A British TV station sent a reporter to pose as a prospective client, and secretly filmed Cambridge Analytica’s chief executive offering to engage in dirty tricks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sitting in a hotel bar, Alexander Nix, who runs the political data firm Cambridge Analytica, had a few ideas for a prospective client looking for help in a foreign election. The firm could send an attractive woman to seduce a rival candidate and secretly videotape the encounter, Mr. Nix said, or send someone posing as a wealthy land developer to pass a bribe.

articles.headline: Facebook Exit Hints at Dissent on Handling of Russian Trolls
articles.snippet: The social network was said to have reached a deal with the executive to depart after disagreements over how to address its role in spreading disinformation.
articles.abstract: The social network was said to have reached a deal with the executive to depart after disagreements over how to address its role in spreading disinformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Facebook grapples with a backlash over its role in spreading disinformation, an internal dispute over how to handle the threat and the public outcry is resulting in the departure of a senior executive.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth, Sheera Frenkel and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Soldier in Bloody Niger Mission Had Warned of Gaps, Defense Officials Say
articles.snippet: Pentagon leaders are said to be troubled by draft conclusions of an inquiry that blames low-level officers in an ambush that killed four American troops.
articles.abstract: Pentagon leaders are said to be troubled by draft conclusions of an inquiry that blames low-level officers in an ambush that killed four American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leader of an ill-fated team of American soldiers in Niger last fall warned before the mission that his troops did not have the equipment or intelligence necessary to carry out a kill-or-capture raid against a local militant, according to preliminary findings of a continuing Defense Department investigation.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: California Housing Problems Are Spilling Across Its Borders
articles.snippet: Reno is among several Western cities experiencing congestion and new tensions as California residents and businesses seek more affordable locations.
articles.abstract: Reno is among several Western cities experiencing congestion and new tensions as California residents and businesses seek more affordable locations.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — A growing homelessness crisis. Complaints about traffic congestion. Worries that the economy is becoming dominated by a wealthy elite.

articles.headline: Up, Up, Up Goes the Economy. Here’s What Could Knock It Down.
articles.snippet: Some economists say the recovery could continue for years. But many see the seeds of the next crisis being sown in government policy choices.
articles.abstract: Some economists say the recovery could continue for years. But many see the seeds of the next crisis being sown in government policy choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans have spent much of the past decade wondering when the economy would recover from the crippling Great Recession. Now, they are considering another question: When, and how, will that recovery end?

articles.headline: Their Pay Has Stood Still. Now Oklahoma Teachers Could Be the Next to Walk.
articles.snippet: After West Virginia, teachers in some other conservative states are protesting over pay and benefits, with a statewide strike looming in Oklahoma at the start of April.
articles.abstract: After West Virginia, teachers in some other conservative states are protesting over pay and benefits, with a statewide strike looming in Oklahoma at the start of April.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — When she woke up one morning last week, Tiffany Bell, a teacher at Hamilton Elementary School here, had $35 in her bank account.

articles.headline: For Austin Bomb Investigators, Each New Blast Offers New Clues
articles.snippet: Investigators in Texas searched for links between an unexploded device at a FedEx shipping facility and a series of recent package bombings.
articles.abstract: Investigators in Texas searched for links between an unexploded device at a FedEx shipping facility and a series of recent package bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: A suspect in the series of bombings that have terrorized Austin, Tex., died early Wednesday, blowing himself up in his vehicle as officers closed in on him, the authorities said. Read the latest updates here.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Serge F. Kovaleski and John Ismay

articles.headline: Facebook Faces Growing Pressure Over Data and Privacy Inquiries
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission is said to be examining whether the social media giant violated a 2011 agreement.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is said to be examining whether the social media giant violated a 2011 agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators and state prosecutors are opening investigations into Facebook. Politicians in the United States and Europe are calling for its chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to testify before them. Investors have cut the value of the social networking giant by about $50 billion in the past two days.
